articles.headline: On Chicago’s West Side, Urgent Needs Collide With Washington Compromises
articles.snippet: Activists say the needs of struggling communities in Chicago and elsewhere vastly exceed the billions Congress is spending.
articles.abstract: Activists say the needs of struggling communities in Chicago and elsewhere vastly exceed the billions Congress is spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Democrats in Washington want to talk about what has made it into President Biden’s domestic legislation. Chris Brown on Chicago’s West Side wants to talk about what has been cut.

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Panel Subpoenas Flynn and Eastman, Scrutinizing Election Plot
articles.snippet: The latest batch of subpoenas from the House select committee investigating the Capitol riot also includes officials from former President Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign.
articles.abstract: The latest batch of subpoenas from the House select committee investigating the Capitol riot also includes officials from former President Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol issued new subpoenas on Monday for a half-dozen allies of former President Donald J. Trump, including his former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, as it moved its focus to an orchestrated effort to overturn the 2020 election.

articles.headline: Starbucks Seeks to Delay Union Election as Vote Nears
articles.snippet: The move, and a visit by the company’s former chief executive days before the scheduled start of balloting at three Buffalo-area stores, reflect the stakes.
articles.abstract: The move, and a visit by the company’s former chief executive days before the scheduled start of balloting at three Buffalo-area stores, reflect the stakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just days before workers at three Starbucks stores in the Buffalo area were scheduled to begin voting on unionization, both labor and management took steps that reflect the high stakes involved, including an attempt by Starbucks on Monday to delay the election.

articles.headline: The Biggest Kink in America’s Supply Chain: Not Enough Truckers
articles.snippet: Long hours and uncomfortable working conditions are leading to a shortage of truck drivers, which has compounded shipping delays in the United States.
articles.abstract: Long hours and uncomfortable working conditions are leading to a shortage of truck drivers, which has compounded shipping delays in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing more than $50,000 in student debt, Michael Gary dropped out of college and took a truck driving job in 2012. It paid the bills, he said, and he could reduce his expenses if he lived mostly out of a truck.
articles.byline: By Madeleine Ngo and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Powell’s Books Survived Amazon. Can It Reinvent Itself After the Pandemic?
articles.snippet: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.
articles.abstract: As much as any city, Portland, Ore., has been through hell. Its landmark store, Powell’s Books, must finally build a viable online business while recapturing its downtown success.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: G.E. Breaks Up With Its Storied Past
articles.snippet: The company, once the epitome of corporate ambition, plans to split itself into three separate companies.
articles.abstract: The company, once the epitome of corporate ambition, plans to split itself into three separate companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the quintessential American company, a corporate behemoth whose ambition matched the country’s.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: As China’s Property Crisis Spreads, Beijing Says There’s Nothing to See
articles.snippet: Global markets just weeks ago were fretting over the possible failure of Evergrande. Now the developer says the worst is over, even as other companies show signs of trouble.
articles.abstract: Global markets just weeks ago were fretting over the possible failure of Evergrande. Now the developer says the worst is over, even as other companies show signs of trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: When times were flush for the property developer China Fortune Land, it bought a trophy soccer club and recruited star athletes from Argentina. These days, the players with the club, Hebei F.C., are on indefinite leave because it can’t afford to keep the lights on.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Joy Dong
